reviewText: I have both sets by the History Channel and I love both of them.  The other (and newer) one by the the History is more accurate and complete in it's presentation of the material; the film quality on the newer set is also better--but I still enjoy watching this set just as much as the newer and more complete one.  I like the insights of the historians who help with the narrative in this older video history.  Perhaps if you can only buy one set you should first get the newer one but if you love reviewing our great American Revolutionary History like I do, you will want to have a copy of both of them.  I have watched this older history so many times I should have worn out my copies--this copy will help you to admire and appreciate our great patriot leaders.  It does not seek to degrade the founders because they were slave owners or because they had personal imperfections as some of the new, more liberal historians are trying to do nowadays.  Our founding father's were not perfect, but they were raised up by God and supported, miraculously, in their efforts to secure a new nation where freedom of religion could be practiced and protected by the law.  And the constitution was not just a stroke of good luck; again, God raised up these wise men to create this special nation of freedom.  I love America, our founders, and this older history is always a joy to watch.  I love it and recommend it along with the other, newer one also produced by the History Channel.
summary: If Your Love American Revolutionary HIstory, You'll Love This Set
Title: N/A

reviewText: THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION: ONE NATION'S RISE TO INDEPENDENCE (The History Channel special miniseries, DVD release 2005, 5 discs, approximately 8 hours total programming with 1 hour per program, two programs per disc and two discs with two biographies each) is a wonderful, engaging documentary that is a golden standard of educational material that is also fun. Obviously this is a product of the early 1990s, but I cannot for the life of me find a date.While I think Bill Kurtis is always the perfect host and narrator, and he certainly does not fail here, this documentary makes me a bit sad. It is I believe the first of its kind to have prominent actors voicing the historical figures (Kelsey Grammer gets top billing as Benedict Arnold) but at least it isn't rife with the lousy acting and crummy makeup we see in EVERY historical documentary today. I think this thing started an annoying, stupid trend. In any case, here you don't have all that much dressed-up reenactment garbage you see today.However, they did make the tiny error of showing actors portraying Ben Franklin and his son William, for example, in passing 'cameos' that the episodes could have certainly excluded. For the life of me, I do not understand all the stupid, splashy Hollywood noise of such production in a documentary. If I wanted to see silly reenactments I'd go to my local park!Yet in itself, REVOLUTION represents the pinnacle of engaging historical documentary. Each disc has two hour-long installments, beginning with America as a solid English colony or commonwealth. The documentary then carries us neatly through the revolutionary spark, the war, the relationship between Washington and Benedict Arnold that will surprise you with its interesting, lively coverage.The whole series ends with America and Britain's wobbly new friendship post-revolution, and as I said the set includes biographies on separate discs of Washington, Ben Franklin, Paul Revere and Benedict Arnold. What is the deal with the emphasis on Arnold I cannot tell you - I'd have preferred a documentary of John Adams.Only one piece of practical advice: this is a very dated program, but I think for the most part that is a plus. The quality and picture are all good and clear. The sound is strong but not so ear-splitting as some modern documentaries. All in all, I do not see how anyone with an interest in the subject can be without this set.
summary: "It's a fine day for a foxhunt ... !!" -General George Washington

reviewText: AN EXCELLENT OVERVIEW OF THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR,VERY MUCH IN KEEPING WITH A & E's USUAL HIGH STANDARDS. I ESPECIALLY LIKED ALL THE SEGMENTS ON BENEDICT ARNOLD, WHO PLAYS A MUCH GREATER ROLE IN THE WAR THAN MOST AMERICANS REALIZE,ASIDE FROM HIS TRAITOROUS BEHAVIOR LATE IN THE CONFLICT. A DEFINITE "MUST HAVE " FOR HISTORY BUFFS, IT IS A PROGRAM THAT YOU WILL WATCH AGAIN AND AGAIN OVER THE YEARS, BECAUSE IT NEVER TIRES IN THE TELLING.

reviewText: Speaking as a history teacher, this is one of the best DVD's I own.  I show it to my American history classes.  They are very well done, well researched.. I would recommend to any teacher or student of history wanting a better understanding of the Revolutionary period.jh

reviewText: This set get a triple A for Accuracy, Authenticity, and Action.Many reviewers (including Amazon's) state that this is dry or boring. I disagree - in fact, I found it engulfing in the least, as did my 15 year old son, for whom I bought it.Setting the stage for the reasons behind the Rev War and carrying on through all the major battles, using old paintings, drawings, as well as re-enactors to carry us through, this set pretty much covers the beginnings of our great nation. I don't know what else could have been done, aside from making an actual movie, to have this documentary be more exciting.This box set of five DVD's also includes separate biographies of three of our Founding Fathers and the most famous traitor in our history.Although a bit pricey, it is a very well-done high quality narration of the Revolutionary War, bringing my history book to life.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A stunning documentary of the politics and military aspects of the American Revolution.  Very well done.  The visuals are captivating and the content is in depth enough to please the most demanding historiphile.
summary: Stunning both visually and in content

reviewText: If you have seen Washington the Warrior or the Washington's Generals programs, watching this series will be very difficult to follow and will be disappointing.  Unlike Washington the Warrior, this DVD is not in high definition and does not have a powerful soundtrack.  In fact the video quality is so poor that it looks like someone dubbed it from VHS.  The information presented is good if you're able to stay awake, but it lacks the cinematic conviction that A&E/History Channel is known for producing.  If you're into American Revolutionary History, you may want to look for other video's/series on the subject.
summary: Good information presented, but lacks cinematic conviction
